items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS reaches rare opposition today

featured_image.name: New images capture rare interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS passing ...

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS reaches a rare and fleeting celestial alignment today, positioning itself directly opposite the sun from Earth's perspective and offering scientists a once-in-decades opportunity to study material from another star system before the enigmatic visitor departs forever.

At 13:00 UTC on January 22, 2026, 3I/ATLAS will align to within just 0.69 degrees of the Earth-Sun axis—an exceptionally small angle that creates ideal conditions for what astronomers call an "opposition surge," a phenomenon that will cause the object to appear brighter and reveal more about its composition. Unlike typical cometary oppositions that last only hours, this alignment will keep 3I/ATLAS within two degrees of the axis for approximately one week.[1][2][3]

items.title: Webb telescope solves mystery of how crystals form in icy comets

featured_image.name: Webb telescope captures 'breathtaking' images of Orion Nebula

items.description:
The James Webb Space Telescope has delivered a striking one-two punch of cosmic discoveries this week, capturing the clearest infrared images ever taken of the Helix Nebula while also solving a decades-old puzzle about how crystals found in comets formed in the frozen reaches of space.

NASA unveiled the new Helix Nebula images on Tuesday, offering an unprecedented look at one of the most photographed planetary nebulas in the sky. Located 650 light-years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius and often called the "Eye of God," the nebula has never appeared with such detail.[1][2][3]

items.title: Shell weighs sale of Argentina shale assets, sources say

featured_image.name: Vaca Muerta shale formation propels Argentina closer to ...

items.description:
Shell is considering selling some or all of its assets in Argentina's Vaca Muerta shale formation, a move that would mark a surprise exit by one of the region's earliest backers just as international interest in the massive play intensifies, according to a Reuters report citing three sources familiar with the matter.[1][2]

The oil major has approached potential buyers in recent weeks to gauge interest in the holdings, which are likely to be valued in the billions of dollars, two of the sources said. However, a sale is not guaranteed, and Shell could still choose to retain the assets. The company declined to comment.[2][3][1]

items.title: Trump and China offer dueling visions on trade at Davos

featured_image.name: New trade map takes shape in Davos as world adjusts to Trump tariffs

items.description:
The 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, became a stage for clashing economic worldviews this week as President Donald Trump defended his aggressive tariff policies while Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng championed multilateralism and free trade—a split that is accelerating the reshaping of global economic alliances.

Trump addressed the forum on Wednesday, touting what he called an "economic miracle" achieved through tariffs that he said slashed the U.S. monthly trade deficit by 77 percent in one year. "Virtually all of the so-called experts predicted my plans to end this failed model would trigger a global recession and runaway inflation. But we have proven them wrong," he declared. He criticized European economic policies, stating that "certain places in Europe are not even recognizable, frankly, anymore."[1]

items.title: Earthquake monitors can track falling space debris, study finds

featured_image.name: China says most rocket debris burned up during re-entry ...

items.description:
Scientists have demonstrated that earthquake monitors can track falling space debris through sonic booms, offering a new method to pinpoint where dangerous fragments land as the skies become increasingly crowded with satellites.

Researchers reported Thursday that seismic readings from sonic booms generated when a discarded Chinese crew capsule module reentered over Southern California in 2024 allowed them to place the object's path nearly 20 miles farther south than radar had predicted from orbit, according to findings published in the journal Science.[1][2][3]

"The problem at the moment is we can track stuff very well in space," said Benjamin Fernando of Johns Hopkins University, the lead researcher. "But once it gets to the point that it's actually breaking up in the atmosphere, it becomes very difficult to track."[2][4]

items.title: EU suspends trade deal approval amid Trump's Greenland push

featured_image.name: E.U. halts approval of U.S. trade deal after Trump's Greenland tariff ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump declared Thursday that the United States would have "total access" to Greenland under a framework agreement reached with NATO, even as the European Union suspended approval of a bilateral trade deal in response to weeks of tariff threats tied to the Arctic territory.

Trump's announcement, made from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, marked an apparent de-escalation after he withdrew his threat to impose 10% tariffs on eight European nations beginning February 1. But the deal's specifics remain unclear, and Denmark has firmly stated its sovereignty is not up for negotiation.

items.title: Gold tops $4,900 per ounce for first time amid global turmoil

featured_image.name: Gold notches record above $4,700/oz, silver hits all-time high

items.description:
Spot gold crossed the $4,900-per-ounce threshold for the first time on Thursday, while platinum surged to an all-time high, as investors piled into precious metals amid escalating geopolitical tensions and turmoil in global bond markets.

The historic rally extends gold's extraordinary run into 2026, with the metal gaining 11% since the start of the year and approximately 75% over the past 12 months. Platinum, meanwhile, rose 3% to reach a record $2,558.20 per ounce, having climbed nearly 160% over the past year.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: NATO to bolster Arctic security after Trump-Rutte discussions

featured_image.name: U.S. President Trump Attends World Economic Forum In Davos

items.description:
Global powers are escalating their competition for dominance in the Arctic as melting ice opens new shipping routes and exposes vast mineral reserves, transforming the region into what military and political leaders describe as a strategic frontier of the 21st century.

The race intensified this week when NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte announced that alliance members would move to enhance Arctic security following discussions with U.S. President Donald Trump at the World Economic Forum in Davos. Rutte told Reuters that NATO would "convene alongside senior commanders to determine what actions are necessary," expressing confidence the alliance could accomplish this "quite swiftly" by 2026.[1]

Finnish President Alexander Stubb said he aims to have an Arctic security strategy ready before the NATO summit scheduled for July in Turkey.[2]

items.title: Trump, Kushner unveil $25B plan to rebuild Gaza at Davos

featured_image.name: US touts 'New Gaza' filled with luxury real estate

items.description:
President Donald Trump and his son-in-law Jared Kushner presented Thursday a sweeping vision to transform war-ravaged Gaza into a luxury coastal destination, unveiling a $25 billion reconstruction plan at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, alongside the formal launch of Trump's "Board of Peace" initiative.

The announcement included a pledge from Ali Shaath, head of the newly formed National Committee for the Administration of Gaza, that the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt would reopen next week for the first time since Israeli forces took control of it in 2024.[1][2][3]

items.title: Scientists find black hole growing 13 times faster than theory allows

featured_image.name: Supermassive black holes shrouded by dust in the early universe

items.description:
An international research team has discovered a supermassive black hole in the early universe growing at 13 times the theoretical speed limit, challenging current models of how these cosmic giants form and evolve.

The discovery, announced Wednesday by scientists at Waseda University and Tohoku University in Japan, used observations from the Subaru Telescope to measure gas motion around a black hole that existed when the universe was less than 1.5 billion years old. The findings, published in The Astrophysical Journal, reveal an object accreting matter at rates that defy conventional astrophysics.[1][2][3]

items.title: Musk predicts AI will surpass all human intelligence within 5 years

featured_image.name: Musk to attend Davos for first time after years of ...

items.description:
Elon Musk made his debut at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Thursday, predicting that robots would eventually outnumber humans and that artificial intelligence would surpass collective human intelligence within five years.

The Tesla and SpaceX chief appeared as a surprise late addition to the forum's schedule, joining BlackRock CEO Larry Fink for a wide-ranging conversation that marked a reversal for the tech billionaire who has previously dismissed the annual gathering as "elitist" and "boring."[1][2][3]

items.title: Moderna halts new vaccine trial investments, citing US opposition

featured_image.name: World Economic Forum Annual Meeting | Stéphane Bancel, Chief ...

items.description:
Moderna will not invest in new late-stage vaccine trials due to growing opposition to immunizations from US officials, Chief Executive Officer Stéphane Bancel announced at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

"You cannot make a return on investment if you don't have access to the US market," Bancel told Bloomberg TV on Wednesday, explaining that regulatory delays and lack of support from US health officials are making the potential market size "much smaller."[1][2][3]

The announcement reflects the deepening chill across the vaccine industry as anti-vaccine rhetoric under Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has translated into concrete policy changes over the past year.

items.title: Google's AI can now search your emails and photos for answers

featured_image.name: Google introduces AI enhancements to gmail, transforming ...

items.description:
Google is expanding its "Personal Intelligence" AI feature to its flagship search engine's AI Mode, allowing the company's Gemini chatbot to analyze users' emails, photos, and YouTube history to deliver customized search results. The expansion, announced Wednesday, follows the initial January 14 rollout of Personal Intelligence in the standalone Gemini app.

The feature marks a significant shift in how Google handles user data for AI-powered services. When enabled, Gemini can reason across a user's Gmail, Google Photos, and YouTube viewing history to provide tailored answers to search queries—from finding license plate numbers stored in photos to suggesting vacation destinations based on past travel patterns.

"Personal Intelligence securely connects information from apps like Gmail and Google Photos to make Gemini uniquely helpful," Josh Woodward, Google's vice president overseeing the Gemini app, wrote in a blog post. "You control exactly which apps to link, and each one supercharges the experience."[1]

items.title: Japan's largest nuclear plant halts restart hours after launch

featured_image.name: TOPSHOT-JAPAN-NUCLEAR-PLANT-ENERGY-RESTART

items.description:
Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings launched its first reactor since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster on Wednesday evening, only to suspend operations hours later after an alarm sounded during startup procedures—underscoring the persistent technical challenges facing Japan's nuclear revival.

The No. 6 reactor at the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant in Niigata Prefecture was reactivated at 7:02 p.m. local time on Wednesday and reached criticality around 90 minutes later. But at 12:28 a.m. Thursday, an alarm from a control rod monitoring system triggered a halt to operations, forcing TEPCO to suspend the withdrawal of control rods essential for regulating nuclear fission.[1][2]

items.title: Trump, Zelensky meet in Davos as US envoys head to Moscow

featured_image.name: Trump praises Zelensky meeting in Davos as very good amid ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met behind closed doors at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday in an hour-long discussion that came as U.S. envoys prepared to travel to Moscow for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Zelensky's spokesperson Serhii Nykyforov said the two leaders engaged in a "brief one-on-one conversation" after the meeting concluded, with Trump telling reporters the encounter was "good." Media advisor Dmytro Lytvyn described the session as "productive."[1]

items.title: Zelensky criticizes Europe, confirms trilateral peace talks

featured_image.name: Zelensky's Address at Davos

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivered a blistering speech at the World Economic Forum on Thursday, accusing European allies of paralysis in the face of Russian aggression while announcing the first trilateral meeting between Ukraine, the United States, and Russia would take place in the UAE starting Friday.

Speaking shortly after an hour-long meeting with US President Donald Trump in Davos, Zelensky said Europe was "living in Groundhog Day," stuck in a pattern of inaction nearly four years into Russia's invasion. "Just last year here in Davos, I ended my speech with the words Europe needs to know how to defend itself. A year has passed and nothing has changed," he said.[1][2]

items.title: Zelensky slams Europe's 'lack of political will' on Russia at Davos

featured_image.name: As Trump Takes Office, Zelensky Urges Europe to Stand Firm ...

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivered a sharp critique of European leaders during his address at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Thursday, accusing the European Union of lacking "political will" in dealing with Russia and warning that the continent has made no progress on self-defense in the past year.

"Just last year, here in Davos, I ended my speech with the words: Europe needs to know how to defend itself. A year has passed. And nothing has changed," Zelensky told the gathering of global leaders and business executives. "Instead of becoming a truly global power, Europe remains a beautiful but fragmented kaleidoscope of small and middle powers," he added.[1][2][3][4]

The Ukrainian leader accused European nations of preferring discussion over action. "Europe loves to discuss the future but avoids taking action today — actions that determine what future we will have, that is the problem," Zelensky said. He specifically criticized European leaders for blocking the use of frozen Russian assets to help fund Ukraine's defense.[5][6][7]

items.title: Trump administration seeks Cuba regime change by year's end

featured_image.name: Trump seeks to topple Cuba’s communist government by year’s end, report says

items.description:
The Trump administration is actively pursuing regime change in Cuba before the end of 2026, seeking insiders within the Communist government who might be willing to negotiate an end to nearly seven decades of one-party rule, according to a report published Wednesday by The Wall Street Journal.

The effort, emboldened by the January 3 capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, marks a sharp escalation in Washington's pressure campaign against Havana. U.S. officials told the Journal they believe Cuba's economy is "nearing collapse" and that the government has never been more vulnerable, particularly after losing its main oil supplier in Caracas.[1][2]

items.title: Trump launches 'Board of Peace' at Davos as UK, France decline

featured_image.name: Trump launches 'Board of Peace' at Davos signing ceremony ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump formally unveiled his "Board of Peace" initiative at a signing ceremony during the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday, calling it "a very exciting day, long in the making" as he stood alongside leaders from nearly 20 nations.[1][2][3]

"We're going to have peace in the world," Trump declared. "And we're all stars." The ceremony marks the official launch of an initiative originally conceived to oversee Gaza's reconstruction but which has since expanded into a far broader organization aimed at mediating global conflicts.[1]

items.title: US and China approve TikTok spinoff deal set to close this week

featured_image.name: TikTok U.S. Sale Set to Close in January With Oracle, Silver Lake

items.description:
The United States and China have approved a deal to sell TikTok's US business to a consortium of mostly American investors led by Oracle and Silver Lake, ending a yearslong dispute between the social media platform and the two superpowers, according to Semafor.[1]

The agreement, which ByteDance CEO Shou Zi Chew outlined in an internal memo in December, is set to close this week, according to people familiar with the matter. The deal's completion would remove a sticking point in US-China relations at a time when tensions are running high and secure the platform's future for its 170 million American users.[2][3][1]
